head.title: Behind the Scenes;A Short Cut Into Virtual Reality

hedline.hl1: Behind the Scenes;A Short Cut Into Virtual Reality

block.p: While Michael Douglas thumbed through his employer's secret files with ease in "Disclosure" using a virtual reality program, the actual applications of that technology are are more suited to the fields of architecture, electronic games and business presentations.

But everyday users cannot create virual reality scenes easily. Conventional virtual reality applications require huge amounts of computing power to generate realistic scenes. Trying to generate scenes in real time on a computer is akin to trying to stuff an elephant into a hall closet. A scaled-down alternative is Apple's Quicktime VR, a technology for creating and displaying scenes made from photographs, video stills or computer renderings. Programmers are just beginning to use the technology for games and architectural applications.

A scaled-down alternative is Apple's Quicktime VR, a technology for creating and displaying scenes made from photographs, video stills or computer renderings. Programmers are just beginning to use the technology for games and architectural applications.

Each scene is roughly 500 kilobytes, about one-third of a floppy disk. Programmers can link one scene to another to create a virtual world, or house or factory. Strata Studio Pro and Metatools KPT Bryce allow the user to export files into Quicktime VR for virtual worlds.
The technology's overall effect, while comparatively low-techology, bypasses most the limitations of today's computing platforms.
